Award.AwardTitle: AGS/EAR-PRF: Confronting Multi-scale Complexity in the Dynamics of Regional U.S. Land-atmosphere Coupling Energetics and Their Links to Climate Variability and Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hosted by Professors Famiglietti and Pritchard at the University of California, Irvine, the principal investigator (P.I.) will seek to clarify the role of land surface coupling in the evolution of organized convection and rainfall in the Central United States (US). The strategy will be to employ novel methodological techniques to isolate and measure components of the energy exchange system between the land and atmosphere, in a uniquely multi-scale virtual laboratory. By deconstructing nonlinear complexities in land-atmosphere coupling feedbacks using individual component amplification, and attributing responses, the author will develop a holistic physical framework and apply it to the following questions:

1. What is the role of land surface coupling in generating and sustaining mesoscale convective systems and summer precipitation in the Central US?
2. How critical is explicitly resolved land heterogeneity for realistically representing mesoscale land-convection interactions in the context of regional and global hydrology?
3. Are irrigation-driven hydro-climate feedbacks robust to a realistic representation of the mechanisms that drive convective precipitation in the Central US?
4. How will mesoscale convection and its interaction with the natural and manmade water cycles change in future climate? Do land-surface feedbacks play a role in mediating the response?

Intellectual Merit:
Land-atmosphere coupling in the Central US plays an especially critical role in mediating local weather and climate. How the hydrological cycle will respond to the anthropogenic influences of irrigation and climate change depends on a complex set of land-surface energy exchange mechanisms whose coupled behavior is difficult to understand. Advancing knowledge at this hydrologic interface requires insight into its nonlinear sensitivities through controlled multi-scale numerical experiments, including links to non-local and global feedbacks on column energetics. Focusing on Central US hydro-climate and its response to irrigation and climate change, the author seeks to make progress on this front. The research builds on the author's doctoral experience applying fundamental principles of atmospheric physics to investigate mesoscale convection, climate change, and aerosol-cloud interactions in simulations from conventional and super-parameterized global climate models. The co-mentoring strategy combines the diverse expertise of Professors Famiglietti and Pritchard in atmospheric and hydrologic science to address frontier scientific questions at the interface of their individual research foci.

Broader Impacts:
The broader impact activities and co-mentoring plan will strengthen land-atmosphere coupling in research and graduate level education at the University of California, Irvine, and with policy makers who have a stake in the land-atmosphere interface in the Central US. The P.I. will help launch a graduate seminar series focused on land-atmosphere interactions, bringing together experts in hydrology and climate science to foster interdisciplinary research and cross-pollination of frontier science ideas. The P.I. will expand public partnerships with policy makers, researchers, and educators that have been developed by the NSF Center for Multiscale Modeling of Atmospheric Processes in the Central US to directly link the research to relevant stakeholders through public outreach activities. These efforts will help spread new research results and experience to both the scientific community and general public, and guide the P.I.'s own professional development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactions between the land and atmosphere control many aspects of the climate system that are critical to society, including availability of freshwater, intensity of floods, frequency of droughts, and prevalence of heat waves. Improving our ability to project how these events are affected by climate change requires understanding of the physical feedbacks that control the exchange of energy and moisture between these systems. These interactions are especially important in transition regions between arid and moist conditions, such as the Central United States, where changes to either the land or atmosphere can impact the regional hydrologic system. Rainfall is a particularly important component of this interaction, since its coupled feedbacks with soil moisture influence the partitioning of turbulent and latent energy fluxes from the land-surface. In addition to total rainfall, the intensity of rain can impact hydrological (e.g. soil infiltration) and biosphere (e.g. transpiration) processes by constraining surface runoff and vegetation rainwater intercept. Unfortunately, current global models fail to simulate rainfall intensity realistically, due in part to an inability to capture the organized convective storms that generate it.

Progress in understanding this complicated system is a grand challenge for Earth system science, and improving future projections requires a modeling system capable of accurately simulating the flow of water and energy across the land-surface interface at a range of scales, including links to global-scale feedbacks. This project employed new techniques to identify, evaluate the present-day representation of, and assess the future climate change response of important physical processes using a novel multi-scale modeling technology called superparameterization. This modeling approach avoids the unrealistic idealizations of small-scale processes used in conventional models by embedding an explicit cloud-resolving model in each column of a global model to simulate convection, clouds, rainfall, and land-atmosphere interactions on their native scales. Applying this modeling framework, this project has produced several publications investigating convective rainfall intensity and its impact on land-atmosphere interactions. 

Taking a broad view of rainfall on global-scales, we developed a comprehensive set of metrics for evaluating the full character of simulated rainfall intensity compared to observations. These metrics look beyond average conditions to higher-order statistics (e.g. frequency and intensity), of which future changes are uncertain, especially in regions of organized storm systems (i.e. tropics and mid-latitude summers). This work demonstrates that superparameterization improves the representation of both moderate and extreme rain relative to satellite observations, particularly in regions of tropical waves, the Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons (modes of variability not well represented in conventional models) [Kooperman et al., 2016a]. These regions also have large projected intensifications of rainfall across all rain rates, most significantly over India and Asia, where these modes of variability are amplified [Kooperman et al., 2016b]. This result is insensitive to horizontal scale, unlike conventional models, which are unable to capture this response due to the limitations and resolution dependence of convective parameterizations [Kooperman et al., 2016c].

Focusing on the Central United States in particular, we evaluated projected changes in summer thunderstorms that deliver the majority of rain to the region and can cause severe flooding.
